bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 30, 1940

div1.p: Kean describes answering Hench's questions about the yellow fever experiments. Kean mentions that his wife is upset about his diary being sent through mail for Hench's research, and is afraid it might get lost. He reminisces about his stay in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 30, 1940
div1.opener:
Gen A. E. Truby
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sept. 30 1940
My dear Truby
div1.p:
Your Air Mail letter of
Sept. 10 reached me on the 12th
but my letter returning your most inter-
esting article with my comments on
it had been mailed to you on
the 6th and must have reached
you almost immediately after
you got off your letter- I think
all your letter of the 10th was an-
swered in my letter and my
comments so I have not felt that
an answer was necessary- But
it should have been acknowledged
any way and has been leaning
against my big inkstand ever since
C2
B5
2
reminding me that I should do
so- My reply to Dr. Hench's ques-
tionnaire was in the form of
a very long letter and was in
long hand as I have no conve-
nient way of getting hold of a
steno-Tho. Dr. Hench has sev-
eral times asked me to hire
one and let him pay the bill-
He was very Keen to see again
my diary for the autumn of 1900
and so I, against Cornelia's
protest at risking it loss,
sent him that volume by express
with the M. S.S and my address
at the dedication of Read's birth-
place at Belroi in Gloucester Co. Va
Oct. 15, 1927 which you may recollect
contained mainly remeniscences of the
3
of the yellow fever episode-

I feel with you that Dr. Hench is
so earnest and has gone to so much
work and expense to get at all the
facts and is besides so entirely
disinterested in the matter- That
we should give him all the
help we can- I have written to
him that your memory for details
was better than mine and your
contacts with the work of the board
so much closer, so I felt that,
where there was any difference
in our, statements, he should take
yours- My diary is lamentable
scanty as I was much on the
go with inspections and fussing
our old Clara Bartons 16 orphan
asylums that she left on my door-
step
without any means of support or even
any records or lists of inmates or
employes- Also the chief Q. M. Hum-
phies was giving us lots of trouble
by going a head to build hospitals
and make sanitary arrangements
not only, without consulting the
Medical Department, andbut in
some cases against my strongest
protests in which I was in all
cases backed up by the chief
Surgeon (O Reilly & Havard) we acquired
a modus vivendi with him after he
became Q. M.General but as Chief Q
M. of Cuba he was a pest-

Things move at such a pace now here
that they take one's breath away even
a by stander like myself- Ireland
& I were rejoicing this morning that
AG. Love& Wallace Dewitt should
have been made Brig. Generals in the
big list-
Affectionate regards to you and your dear wife
